title: 111_hr844
content: The Marine Mammal Rescue Assistance Amendments of 2009, also known as the Marine Mammal Protection Act, has been updated to include entanglement response agreements. This amendment allows for the collection and updating of information on stranded or entangled marine mammals. The Marine Mammal Protection Act has been amended to include entanglement response agreements, defining entanglement as gear wrapped around a marine mammal in the wild. The Marine Mammal Protection Act has been amended to increase funding for the John H. Prescott Marine Mammal Rescue Assistance Grant Program, with appropriations raised to $7,000,000 for fiscal years 2010 through 2013. Administrative costs and expenses have also been adjusted accordingly. The Marine Mammal Protection Act has been amended to allocate all funds for eligible stranding network participants, with a limit of 6% or $80,000 for administrative costs. Unused funds for administrative expenses will be provided as grants. The Marine Mammal Protection Act has been amended to allow the Secretary to enter into agreements for emergency stranding events without funding limits. The Marine Mammal Protection Act has been amended to include provisions for emergency assistance in response to stranding events without requiring non-Federal contributions. The Marine Mammal Protection Act has been amended to include provisions for emergency assistance in response to stranding events that lead to immediate cost increases, may be cyclical or endemic, and involve out-of-habitat animals. Additionally, the Secretary is authorized to solicit and use gifts for carrying out this section. Authorization of appropriations for the Marine Mammal Unusual Mortality Event Fund has been extended for fiscal years 2010 through 2013. The Marine Mammal Protection Act was amended to provide emergency assistance for stranding events with immediate cost increases. The Secretary can now use gifts for this purpose. Authorization for the Marine Mammal Unusual Mortality Event Fund has been extended for fiscal years 2010 through 2013. The bill passed the House of Representatives on March 2, 2009.
